questions.title: Question 001
questions.question: Which statement is correct regarding passing permissions to reusable workflows?

choices.text: The `GITHUB_TOKEN` permissions passed from the caller workflow can be only downgraded by the called workflow.
The `GITHUB_TOKEN` permissions passed from the caller workflow can be only elevated by the called workflow.
The `GITHUB_TOKEN` permissions passed from the caller workflow can be both downgraded and elevated by the called workflow.
The `GITHUB_TOKEN` permissions passed from the caller workflow can be neither downgraded or elevated by the called workflow.

questions.explanation: The GITHUB_TOKEN permissions can only be downgraded by the called workflow, not elevated, for security reasons.

questions.title: Question 002
questions.question: What are the different permission levels you can assign to `GITHUB_TOKEN` in the `permissions` block?
questions.explanation: The three permission levels for GITHUB_TOKEN are: none (no permissions), read (read-only access), and write (read and write access).

questions.title: Question 003
questions.question: You can use `permissions` to modify the `GITHUB_TOKEN` permissions on: (Select two.)
questions.explanation: You can set permissions at both the workflow level (applies to all jobs) and job level (overrides workflow level for that specific job). Permissions cannot be set at the step level.

questions.title: Question 004
questions.question: Are GitHub Actions free for public repositories?
questions.explanation: GitHub Actions is free for all public repositories.

questions.title: Question 005
questions.question: Which of these is not a valid event that could trigger a workflow?

choices.text: Committing a file to master branch
Adding a label to a pull request

questions.explanation: Cloning a repository does not trigger a workflow. Workflows are triggered by events such as pushes, pull requests, and branch creation.

questions.title: Question 006
questions.question: Which is true about workflows? (Select three.)

choices.text: Workflows can run one or multiple jobs at a time
Workflows can be triggered manually, by an event or run on a schedule
Workflows have to be defined in the `.github/workflows` directory
Workflows can only be run on a schedule
Workflow can run only one job at a time
Workflows are written in any of `.yaml`, `.json` or `.toml` formats
Workflows can be shared in GitHub Marketplace

questions.explanation: Workflows can run multiple jobs, be triggered in various ways, and must be in the `.github/workflows` directory. They can't be shared on the Marketplace, and are written in YAML.

questions.title: Question 007
questions.question: Which components are required for a workflow? (Select two.)

choices.text: One or more events that will trigger the workflow
Defined branches on which the workflow will run

questions.explanation: A workflow must have at least one event trigger and at least one job. A name and branch definition are optional.

questions.title: Question 008
questions.question: Which event is triggered by a webhook action from outside of the repository?
questions.explanation: The `repository_dispatch` event is used to trigger a workflow from an external webhook.

questions.title: Question 009
questions.question: Workflows are defined in which format
questions.explanation: Workflows are defined using YAML syntax.

questions.title: Question 010
questions.question: Where should you store sensitive data such as passwords or certificates that will be used in workflows
questions.explanation: Sensitive data should be stored as encrypted secrets.

questions.title: Question 011
questions.question: In a workflow with multiple jobs the default behavior is:
questions.explanation: By default, all jobs in a workflow run in parallel.

questions.title: Question 012
questions.question: If job B requires job A to be finished you have to:

choices.text: use the `needs` keyword in job B to create this dependency
use the `needs` keyword in job A to create this dependency
use the `requires` keyword in job B to create this dependency
use the `requires` keyword in job A to create this dependency

questions.explanation: The `needs` keyword is used in the dependent job (job B) to specify that it depends on another job (job A).

questions.title: Question 013
questions.question: In a workflow with multiple jobs, if job A fails then:

choices.text: the jobs that are dependent on job A are skipped
the jobs that are dependent on job A fail
the workflow immediately cancels all other jobs

questions.explanation: If a job fails, any jobs that depend on it are skipped.

questions.title: Question 014
questions.question: This code will launch 6 different jobs in parallel using the matrix strategy. Can you use the matrix strategy to parallelize entire workflows?
questions.explanation: You can use a matrix strategy to run a reusable workflow multiple times with different inputs.

questions.title: Question 015
questions.question: Which matrix job definition is syntactically correct?

choices.text:
jobs:
  example_matrix:
    strategy:
      matrix:
        version: [10, 12, 14]
        os: [ubuntu-latest, windows-latest]

jobs:
  example_matrix:
    matrix:
      strategy:
        version: [10, 12, 14]
        os: [ubuntu-latest, windows-latest]

jobs:
  example_matrix:
    matrix:
      version: [10, 12, 14]
      os: [ubuntu-latest, windows-latest]

questions.explanation: The correct syntax for a matrix is to define it under the `strategy` key within a job.

questions.title: Question 016
questions.question: How do you access matrix variables in a matrix strategy job?
questions.explanation: Matrix variables are accessed through the `matrix` context.

questions.title: Question 017
questions.question: When using the `pull_request` and `pull_request_target` events, how do you configure the workflow to run only when targeting the `prod` branch?

choices.text: You create the workflow only on `prod` branch

questions.explanation: The `branches` filter is used to specify which branches the workflow should run on for pull request events.

questions.title: Question 018
questions.question: This workflow will run on all pull requests where:

choices.text: the target branch name starts with `release` but does not end with `-alpha`
the target branch name starts with `release`
the source branch name starts with `release` but does not end with `-alpha`
the source branch name starts with `release`

questions.explanation: The `branches` filter with the `pull_request` event targets the *target* branch. The `!` character excludes branches that match the pattern.

questions.title: Question 019
questions.question: Fill in the blank: When using `push` event trigger filters you can use <____> patterns to target multiple branches
questions.explanation: Glob patterns are used to target multiple branches or tags with the `push` event trigger.

questions.title: Question 020
questions.question: Which event allows you to manually trigger a workflow from the GitHub UI?
questions.explanation: The `workflow_dispatch` event allows you to manually trigger a workflow.

questions.title: Question 021
questions.question: What are the possible types of an input variable for a manually triggered workflow? (Select five.)
questions.explanation: The possible input types for a manually triggered workflow are: `choice`, `boolean`, `string`, `number`, and `environment`.

questions.title: Question 022
questions.question: A workflow that has only `workflow_dispatch` event trigger can be triggered using GitHub's REST API
questions.explanation: You can trigger a `workflow_dispatch` event using the REST API.

questions.title: Question 023
questions.question: To stop a workflow from running temporarily without modifying the source code you should

choices.text: Use the `Disable workflow` option in GitHub Actions
Remove secrets that are required for this workflow
Delete environment that is required for this workflow
Prevent any new commits to main branch

questions.explanation: You can temporarily disable a workflow from the GitHub Actions UI.

questions.title: Question 024
questions.question: What are `activity types` of an event used for ?

choices.text: Limiting workflow runs to specific activity types using the `types` filter
Checking if the activity comes from an user or a bot
Reacting to new activity on a repository (e.g new contributor)

questions.explanation: Activity types are used with the `types` filter to limit when a workflow runs based on the specific action that triggered the event.

questions.title: Question 025
questions.question: You want to create a reusable workflow `CI` that runs some quality checks, linting and tests on code changes. What event trigger should the `CI` workflow define to allow reusing it in other workflows?
questions.explanation: The `workflow_call` event trigger is used to create a reusable workflow.

questions.title: Question 026
questions.question: A reusable workflow named `build` creates zip file artifacts. How do you pass the zip file location to the caller workflow that is calling the `build` workflow? (Select three.)

choices.text: You define an output on workflow level in the `build` workflow
You define an output on job level in the `build` workflow
In the `build` workflow you write the output into `$GITHUB_OUTPUT` in one of the steps
All outputs are automatically passed to the caller workflows

questions.explanation: You can pass outputs from a reusable workflow to a caller workflow by defining outputs at the workflow or job level, and by writing to `$GITHUB_OUTPUT` in a step.

questions.title: Question 027
questions.question: What are the valid use cases for using **defaults**? (Select two.)

choices.text: Using defaults.run on workflow level to set default shell (e.g bash) for an entire workflow
Using defaults.run on job level to set default working-directory for all steps in a single job
Using defaults.run on step level to set default shell (e.g bash) for that single step
Using defaults.env on workflow level to set default environment variables for an entire workflow
Using defaults.env on job level to set default environment variables for all steps in a single job

questions.explanation: The `defaults` key can be used at the workflow or job level to set default `run` settings, such as `shell` and `working-directory`.

questions.title: Question 028
questions.question: How can you ensure that a workflow called `Deploy Prod` is always running at most one at a time?
questions.explanation: The `concurrency` key can be used at the workflow level to ensure that only one run of the workflow is active at a time.

questions.title: Question 029
questions.question: Your Pull Request analysis workflow uses multiple code analysis tools and takes about 20minutes to fully complete. It is triggered on `pull_request` event with `branches` filter set to `master`. Therefore if a developer pushes multiple commits within few minutes multiple workflows are running in parallel. How can you stop all previous workflow runs and only run the one with latest changes?
questions.explanation: The `concurrency` key with `cancel-in-progress: true` will cancel any in-progress runs of the same workflow on the same branch.

questions.title: Question 030
questions.question: When will job3 run?

choices.text: job3 will run after job1 and job2 have completed, regardless of whether they were successful
You cannot use `if: ${{ always() }}` and `needs` together. The workflow will fail on startup.
job3 will run after job1 and job2 have been successfully completed
job3 will run after both job1 and job2 have failed

questions.explanation: The `always()` function ensures that the job will run regardless of the success or failure of its dependencies.

questions.title: Question 031
questions.question: What `jobs.job_id.if` conditional will make sure that job `production-deploy` is triggered only on `my-org/my-repo` repository? (Select two.)
questions.explanation: You can use the `github.repository` context to check the repository name.

questions.title: Question 032
questions.question: What GitHub-hosted runner types are available to use? (Select three.)
questions.explanation: GitHub provides runners for Windows, Linux (Ubuntu), and macOS.

questions.title: Question 033
questions.question: Is this statement true? `Not all steps run actions, but all actions run as a step`
questions.explanation: A step can run a command or an action. An action is always run as a step.

questions.title: Question 034
questions.question: For any action published in GitHub Marketplace, you can often use it in multiple versions, which approach is the most stable and secure?
questions.explanation: Referencing the commit SHA is the most stable and secure way to use an action, as it ensures you are using a specific, immutable version.

questions.title: Question 035
questions.question: To prevent a job from failure when one of the steps fails you can include:
questions.explanation: The `continue-on-error` flag in a step will prevent the job from failing if that step fails.

questions.title: Question 036
questions.question: You defined a matrix job `example_matrix`. How can limit the matrix to run a maximum of 2 jobs at a time?

choices.text: Use GitHub's REST API to check if the job count is lesser than 2
It's not possible, a matrix will always run all of the jobs in parallel if there are runners available

questions.explanation: The `max-parallel` key in the strategy is used to limit the number of concurrent jobs in a matrix.

questions.title: Question 037
questions.question: Which of these is a proper way of setting an output parameter `PET` with a value of `DOG` in a `step`.
questions.explanation: To set an output parameter, you write to the `$GITHUB_OUTPUT` environment file with the format `key=value`.

questions.title: Question 038
questions.question: Which of these is a way of using `action_state` in `step_two`?
questions.explanation: When an environment variable is set using `$GITHUB_ENV`, it can be accessed directly in subsequent steps of the same job.

questions.title: Question 039
questions.question: Is this statement true? `Workflows can be reused, but a reusable workflow cannot call another reusable workflow.`
questions.explanation: Reusable workflows can be nested, but there are some limitations.

questions.title: Question 040
questions.question: In the following example, `workflow A` passes all of its secrets to `workflow B`, by using the inherit keyword. Then `workflow B` calls `workflow C`. Which statement regarding `secrets` is true for that example?

choices.text: All secrets available to `workflow A` will be also available to `workflow B`, but not to `workflow C`
All secrets from `octo-org` organization and `octo-org/example-repo` repository will be available to `workflow B`, but not to `workflow C`
All secrets available to `workflow A` will be also available to `workflow B` and `workflow C`
Only repository and environment secrets available to `workflow A` will be available to `workflow B`, but not to `workflow C`. Organization scoped secrets cannot be inherited

questions.explanation: Secrets must be explicitly passed to each nested workflow.

questions.title: Question 041
questions.question: When should you use `caching`?

choices.text: When you want to reuse files that don't change often between jobs or workflow runs, such as build dependencies from a package management system.
When you want to reuse files that do change often between jobs or workflow runs, such as build dependencies from a package management system.
When you want to save files produced by a job to view after a workflow run has ended, such as built binaries or build logs.
When you want to save binaries produced by a build job to use in a subsequent deploy job to deploy a new version of an application

questions.explanation: Caching is ideal for reusing files that don't change often, such as build dependencies.

questions.title: Question 042
questions.question: When should you use `artifacts`? (Select two.)

choices.text: Use artifacts to save files produced by a job to view after a workflow run has ended, such as test results or build logs.
Use artifacts to save binaries produced by a build job to use in a subsequent deploy job to deploy a new version of an application
Use artifacts to reuse files that don't change often between jobs or workflow runs, such as build dependencies from a package management system.
Use artifacts to create new versions of your application together with release notes, mentions and/or contributors

questions.explanation: Artifacts are used to save files produced during a workflow run and to pass data between jobs.

questions.title: Question 043
questions.question: If a workflow runs on a `feature-a` branch, can it restore `caches` created in the default `main` branch?

choices.text: Yes, all branches can restore caches created on the default branch
Yes, all caches can be accessed by workflows on any branch within the same repository
No, caches can only be restored from the same branch
Yes but only if no files were changed on `feature-a` branch

questions.explanation: A workflow can restore caches created on the default branch.

questions.title: Question 044
questions.question: To access an `artifact` that was created in another, previously triggered workflow run you can:

choices.text: You cannot access `artifacts` that were created in a different workflow run
Use the `actions/download-artifact` action and make sure the artifact is not expired

questions.explanation: Artifacts are only available to the workflow run that created them.

questions.title: Question 045
questions.question: What should you use to store coverage reports or screenshots generated during a workflow that runs automated testing for a repository?
questions.explanation: Artifacts are ideal for storing files generated during a workflow run, such as test reports and screenshots.

questions.title: Question 046
questions.question: You can only upload a single file at a time when using `actions/upload-artifact` action
questions.explanation: You can upload multiple files at once using the `actions/upload-artifact` action.

questions.title: Question 047
questions.question: In job `deploy`, if you want to access binaries (containing your application) that were created in job `build` you should

choices.text: upload the binaries as artifacts in `build` and download them in `deploy`
upload the binaries as artifacts in `deploy` and download them in `build`
cache the binaries in `build` and read the files from cache in `deploy`
cache the binaries in `deploy` and read the files from cache in `build`

questions.explanation: To share files between jobs, you should upload them as artifacts in the first job and download them in the second.

questions.title: Question 048
questions.question: A job called `job2` is using artifacts created in `job1`. Therefore it's important to make sure `job1` finishes before `job2` starts looking for the artifacts. How should you create that dependency?

choices.text: create this dependency using the `needs` keyword in `job2`
this dependency is created implicitly when using `actions/download-artifact` to download artifact from `job1`
create this dependency by defining `job2` after `job1` in the workflow's `.yaml` definition
create this dependency using the `concurrency` keyword in `job2`

questions.explanation: The `needs` keyword is used to create a dependency between jobs, ensuring that one job finishes before another one starts.

questions.title: Question 049
questions.question: Which is true about `Starter Workflows` ? (Select three.)

choices.text: They allow users to leverage ready-to-use (or requiring minimal changes) workflow templates
GitHub provides and maintains starter workflows for different categories, languages and tooling
Your organization can create custom starter workflows for users in your organization
Starter workflows cannot call reusable workflows
Starter workflows are a paid GitHub feature
Starter workflows are provided ready-to-use and cannot be modified or enhanced

questions.explanation: Starter workflows are templates that can be used to quickly create new workflows. GitHub provides a set of starter workflows, and organizations can create their own.

questions.title: Question 050
questions.question: Secrets and configuration variables can be scoped to: (Select three.)

choices.text: The entire organization, or selected repositories in an organization
An environment shared across multiple repositories
Multiple repositories that do not share an organization/enterprise
A specific workflow in a repository
A specific job in a workflow

questions.explanation: Secrets and configuration variables can be scoped at the organization, repository, and environment levels.

questions.title: Question 051
questions.question: What are the three types of Actions?
questions.explanation: The three types of actions are Docker container actions, JavaScript actions, and composite actions.

questions.title: Question 052
questions.question: Is this statement true? `Docker container actions are usually slower than JavaScript actions`
questions.explanation: Because of the latency to build and retrieve the container, Docker container actions are slower than JavaScript actions.

questions.title: Question 053
questions.question: When creating a custom GitHub Action you have to store the source code in `.github/workflows` directory
questions.explanation: Workflows are stored in the `.github/workflows` directory, but custom actions can be stored in any location in the repository.

questions.title: Question 054
questions.question: When creating custom GitHub Actions - in what file does all the action `metadata` have to be defined?

choices.text: In the `action.yml` or `action.yaml` file in the action repository
It's edited in GitHub Marketplace UI when published for sharing
In the `action.yml` or `action.yaml` file in the action repository, but it is not required if the action is not meant to be shared and used by the public

questions.explanation: All actions must have a metadata file named `action.yml` or `action.yaml`.

questions.title: Question 055
questions.question: A workflow was initially run on `commit A` and failed. You fixed the workflow with the subsequent `commit B`. When you re-run that workflow it will run with code from which commit?

choices.text: It will run with code from `commit A`
It will run with code from `commit B`
You cannot re-run workflows in GitHub Actions. You have to trigger a new workflow which will run with latest changes
It will trigger two workflows, one with code from `commit A` and one with code from `commit B`

questions.explanation: Re-running a workflow uses the same commit SHA and Git ref of the original event that triggered the workflow run.

questions.title: Question 056
questions.question: How can you require manual approvals by a maintainer if the workflow run is targeting the `production` environment?

choices.text: Setting the required reviewers in the `production` workflow
Manual approvals are not supported by GitHub Actions

questions.explanation: Deployment protection rules can be used to require manual approval for a deployment to a specific environment.

questions.title: Question 057
questions.question: Which is true about environments?

choices.text: Each job in a workflow can reference a single environment.
Each workflow can reference a single environment.
Each job in a workflow can reference a maximum of two environments.
Each workflow can reference a maximum of two environments.

questions.explanation: Each job in a workflow can reference a single environment.

questions.title: Question 058
questions.question: When using GitHub Actions to access resources in one of the cloud providers (such as AWS, Azure or GCP) the safest and recommended way to authenticate is
questions.explanation: OpenID Connect (OIDC) is the recommended way to authenticate to cloud providers from GitHub Actions, as it avoids the need to store long-lived credentials as secrets.

questions.title: Question 059
questions.question: Your open-source publicly available repository contains a workflow with a `pull_request` event trigger. How can you require approvals for workflow runs triggered from forks of your repository?

choices.text: Setup required approvals for fork runs in the repository
Setup deployment protection rules for the repository
Setup branch protection rules for the repository
The workflow will not trigger for forks if using `pull_request` event. If you want to do that you should use `fork_pull_request` event trigger with `require-approval` flag.

questions.explanation: You can require approvals for workflow runs from forks in the repository settings.

questions.title: Question 060
questions.question: Which of the following default environment variables contains the name of the person or app that initiated the workflow run?
questions.explanation: The `GITHUB_ACTOR` environment variable contains the name of the person or app that initiated the workflow.

questions.title: Question 061
questions.question: Which of the following are default environment variables in GitHub Actions? (Select three.)
questions.explanation: `GITHUB_REPOSITORY`, `GITHUB_WORKFLOW`, and `GITHUB_ACTOR` are all default environment variables.

questions.title: Question 062
questions.question: Your organization defines a secret `SomeSecret`, however when you reference that secret in a workflow using `${{ secrets.SomeSecret }}` it provides a different value than expected. What may be the reason for that?

choices.text: The secret `SomeSecret` is also declared in repository scope
The secret `SomeSecret` is also declared in enterprise scope
`${{ secrets.SomeSecret }}` expression is only used for repository scoped secrets
You need to use the GitHub API to access organization scoped secrets

questions.explanation: If a secret with the same name exists at multiple levels, the secret at the lowest level takes precedence. In this case, the repository-level secret is overriding the organization-level secret.

questions.title: Question 063
questions.question: Which is a correct way to print a debug message?
questions.explanation: To print a debug message, you use the format `::debug::message`.

questions.title: Question 064
questions.question: How can organizations which are using GitHub Enterprise Server enable automatic syncing of third party GitHub Actions hosted on GitHub.com to their GitHub Enterprise Server instance?

choices.text: GitHub Enterprise Server has access to all GitHub.com Actions by default
GitHub Enterprise Server cannot use GitHub.com Actions because of it's on-premise nature and no internet access

questions.explanation: GitHub Connect can be used to enable automatic access to GitHub.com Actions from GitHub Enterprise Server.

questions.title: Question 065
questions.question: Where can you find network connectivity logs for a GitHub self-hosted-runner?

choices.text: In the `_diag` folder directly on the runner machine
On GitHub.com on that specific Runner's page
In the job run logs of a job that ran on that Runner
In the job run logs of a job that ran on that Runner with debug logging enabled

questions.explanation: Network connectivity logs for a self-hosted runner can be found in the `_diag` folder on the runner machine.

questions.title: Question 066
questions.question: How can you validate that your GitHub self-hosted-runner can access all required GitHub services?

choices.text: Using a GitHub provided script on the runner machine
By trying to access the runner machine by `ssh` to validate the network connectivity
By using the predefined GitHub Actions workflow `network-connectivity.yml`
GitHub will validate the network connectivity automatically when the runner application is installed on the runner machine

questions.explanation: GitHub provides a script that can be run on the runner machine to validate network connectivity.

questions.title: Question 067
questions.question: Which is the correct way of triggering a job only if configuration variable `MY_VAR` has the value of `MY_VALUE`?

choices.text: By creating the following conditional on job level
By creating the following conditional on job level
It's not possible because configuration variables cannot be used in `if` conditionals
It's not possible because configuration variables cannot be used in job level `if` conditionals

questions.explanation: You can use the `vars` context in an `if` conditional to check the value of a configuration variable.

questions.title: Question 068
questions.question: To run a `step` only if the secret `MY_SECRET` has been set, you can:

choices.text: Set the secret `MY_SECRET` as a job level environment variable, then reference that environment variable to conditionally run that step
By creating the following conditional on job level
By creating the following conditional on step level
By creating the following conditional on step level

questions.explanation: Secrets cannot be directly referenced in `if` conditionals. The recommended workaround is to set the secret as an environment variable and then check if the environment variable is set.

questions.title: Question 069
questions.question: How can you use the GitHub API to download workflow run logs?
questions.explanation: You can use a GET request to the `/repos/{owner}/{repo}/actions/runs/{run_id}/logs` endpoint to download workflow run logs.

questions.title: Question 070
questions.question: How can you use the GitHub API to create or update a repository secret?
questions.explanation: You can use a PUT request to the `/repos/{owner}/{repo}/actions/secrets/{secret_name}` endpoint to create or update a repository secret.

questions.title: Question 071
questions.question: How can you override an organization-level GitHub Secret `API_KEY` with a different value when working within a repository? (Select two.)

choices.text: By creating a repository secret with the same name `API_KEY`
By creating a environment secret with the same name `API_KEY`
By creating a enterprise secret with the same name `API_KEY`
By creating a enterprise secret with the name `OVERRIDE_API_KEY`
By creating a repository secret with the name `OVERRIDE_API_KEY`
By creating a environment secret with the name `OVERRIDE_API_KEY`
By creating a repository secret with the name `REPOSITORY_API_KEY`
By creating a environment secret with the name `ENVIRONMENT_API_KEY`

questions.explanation: Secrets at a lower level (repository or environment) will override secrets with the same name at a higher level (organization).

questions.title: Question 072
questions.question: What components can be reused within a GitHub Organization? (Select four.)
questions.explanation: Secrets, configuration variables, self-hosted runners, and workflow templates can all be shared and reused within a GitHub organization.

questions.title: Question 073
questions.question: How many jobs will be executed in the following workflow?
questions.explanation: The matrix will generate 4 jobs (2 pets * 2 colors). The `include` key adds one additional job, for a total of 5.

questions.title: Question 074
questions.question: Which of the following default environment variables contains the full name (e.g `octocat/hello-world`) of the repository where the workflow is running?
questions.explanation: The `GITHUB_REPOSITORY` environment variable contains the full name of the repository.

questions.title: Question 075
questions.question: In a workflow that has multiple jobs, all running on GitHub-hosted runners, is it true that all jobs are guaranteed to run on the same runner machine?
questions.explanation: Each job runs in a fresh instance of a runner image, so there is no guarantee that they will run on the same machine.

questions.title: Question 076
questions.question: What's the maximum amount of reusable workflows that can be called from a single workflow file?
questions.explanation: A single workflow can call up to 20 reusable workflows.

questions.title: Question 077
questions.question: What is a self-hosted runner?

choices.text: A self-hosted runner is a system that you deploy and manage to execute jobs from GitHub Actions on GitHub.com
A self-hosted runner is a system to upload code to a private server
A self-hosted runner is a system to be able to create workloads automatically
A self-hosted runner is a system to manage pull requests from users of the organization

questions.explanation: A self-hosted runner is a system that you deploy and manage to execute jobs from GitHub Actions.

questions.title: Question 078
questions.question: Which of the following is a correct statement about GitHub Workflows and Actions?

choices.text: Each action is composed of one or more workflows which is composed of one or more jobs, and each job is composed of one or more step
Each workflow is composed of one or more action which is composed of one or more jobs, and each job is composed of one or more step
Each workflow is composed of one or more job which is composed of one or more step, and each step is an action or a script
Each action is composed of one or more job which is composed of one or more step, and each step is a workflow

questions.explanation: A workflow is composed of one or more jobs, each job is composed of one or more steps, and each step can be an action or a script.

questions.title: Question 079
questions.question: On which commit and branch do scheduled workflows run in GitHub Actions?

choices.text: Scheduled workflows run on the specific commit on last modified branch.
Scheduled workflows run on the specific commit on the main branch.
Scheduled workflows run on the latest commit on the repository default branch.
Scheduled workflows run on the latest commit on the main branch.

questions.title: Question 080

questions.title: Question 081

questions.title: Question 088

choices.text: Allows defining multiple job configurations to run in parallel

questions.title: Question 097

by searching for a cache in other repositories
